channel.title: Agroforestry on Plum Site
channel.description: Recent content in Agroforestry on Plum Site

item.title: Agroforestry Upland Farm Diversification, Wales
item.description: Table of Contents 1   Diversification of Agriculture 2   Broad Objectives & Constraints 3   Land use, Rural Poverty Problems 4   Pontbren Land Use and Economics 5   Desired Outcomes 6   Objective Strategies, Land Use Changes 7   Upland Diversification Options 8   Finance Tools and Policy Levers for Change 1   Diversification of Agriculture Integrating trees with agriculture is essentially agroforestry land use. Agroforestry practices are skilled and, integrate trees and woody shrubs to enhance sustainability and productivity in agriculture. 2   Broad Objectives & Constraints Land Use Changes To enhance the natural capital and ecosystem functions.

item.title: Economics of Agroforestry
item.description: Subtitle:Key Issues from a Socio-economic perspective Table of Contents 1   Introduction 2   Rationale of Economic Valuation 3   Interpretation, Agroforest Economic Evaluation 4   Agroforest Socioeconomic Analysis 5   Analysis and Viability 6   Adoptibility of Agroforest Systems 7   Conclusion, a Concern for Equity 8   References, Economics of Agroforestry 1   Introduction Agroforestry addresses a wide range of needs at the household/farm level. It has potential for sustainable resource management. Agroforestry (AF) programs must be economically attractive to farmers and sponsors, and fit the context if they are to be successful.

item.title: Enhancing ecosystem and productivity in Oda
item.description: Subtitle:Key Issues from a Socio-economic perspective Designation:MSc. Table of Contents 1   Introduction 2   Causal Analysis 3   Expected Benefits of Agroforestry Interventions 4   Adoption Methods for Agroforestry 5   Follow up Enhancing the sustainability of natural assets to alleviate land-use problems, and thereby reverse decreasing financial and social capital. 1   Introduction Householders report serious problems concerning land use and livelihoods in Oda. Causal analysis indicates poor cycling of nutrients and water with the consequences of soil infertility and flooding.

item.title: Soil Changes Under Agroforestry
item.description: Designation:M.Sc. 532 Table of Contents 1   Objective 2   Introduction 3   Modelling Intercropping with SCUAF 4   How the Model Works in the Simulation 5   Inputs SCUAF 6   Universal Soil Loss Equation 7   Erosion & Fertility 8   Analysis of Results 9   Nutrient Cycle 10   Plant growth 11   Conclusion 12   References SCUAF 13   Appendix 2 1   Objective Compare soil erosion, loss of top soil, and nutrients (N and P) between Glyricidia hedgerow inter-cropped with maize, and maize mono-cropping systems in Lampung, Indonesia.

item.title: Modelling Silvopasture Light, Water and Growth
item.description: Table of Contents 1   Objective 2   Design 3   Introduction & Background 4   Models 5   Results and Analysis 6   Conclusions, Silvopasture light and water 7   Interpretation & Discussion of AF SP Model 8   References, Silvopasture Light, Water 1   Objective To investigate light and water availability in interactions, facilitatory or competitive, in growth of silvopasture. 2   Design Silvopasture with monocrop control conditions, at the Henfaes Research centre, N. Wales. Specifically, Sycamore (Acer Pseudoplatinus) and Rye (L. Perrene) in 10 x 10 meter spacing.

item.title: Agricultural Policies to Mitigate Flooding
item.description: Table of Contents 1   Abstract 2   Flooding, Current Perceptions and Objectives 3   Strategic Issues in Sustainable Land-Use 4   Integrating Agriculture With Policy to Mitigate Flooding 5   Conclusions 6   References, Flooding Advising the Welsh National Assembly 1   Abstract With the cost of flood damage and defense, loss of biodiversity and over-exploitation of soils, present intensive development of flood plains and drainage of wetlands is not sustainable. Moreover, livelihoods are threatened by over production in farming. Agroforestry practices can be used to mitigate flooding, especially from upland run off.

item.title: Modelling Interactions in Shifting Mosaics
item.description: Designation:MSc. 531 Table of Contents 1   Objective 2   Rationale 3   The Crop Down Fallow Up Assumptions 4   Structure of CDFU Model 5   Af Intervention 6   Testing Interventions 7   Third Run 8   Fourth Run 9   Fifth Run 10   Conclusions CDFU Model 11   References, Shifting Mosaic Models Investigation of the extent to which AF Interventions may allow for a higher population density whilst maintaining a food sufficiency of 100%. 1   Objective Using Van Noordwijk's Crop Down Fallow Up (CDFU) model, to investigate the extent to which interventions may allow for a higher population density whilst maintaining a food sufficiency of 100%.

item.title: Modelling Silvopasture Canopy and Growth
item.description: Table of Contents 1   Aim of the Assignment 2   The Agroforestry Trial 3   How a Model of Silvopasture Was Built 4   Evaluation of Running the Model 5   Further Considerations of Silvopasture Model 1   Aim of the Assignment Growth data from current agroforestry trials in Columbia were to be modelled using AME's Simile object - based computer programme. The trails included three strata of shrub, arboreal (i.e. fruit trees) and timber trees, over pasture. 2   The Agroforestry Trial Shrubs had been planted at a density of 625 ha-1, arboreal trees at 144 ha-1, and timber at 36 ha-1.

item.title: Representing Agroforest Systems Baltistan
item.description: Table of Contents 1   Representing the Livelihood System 2   Analysis of Agroforest 3   Analysis of Pasture, Silvopasture 4   Household Activities On and Off-farm Baltistan is characterised by diversity in land use, self-sufficiency and sustainable agricultural practices in an environment constrained by short growing seasons, fragile mountain environment and small land holdings. Movement of dung, produced by seasonal grazing of herds at higher altitudes, maintains fertility and structure of the lower cropland soils. Exhaustion or destabilisation of soils would take at least two hundred years to recover.

item.title: Representing Local Knowledge, Atwima
item.description: Designation:MSc. Table of Contents 1   A Computer Knowledge Base 2   Boolean Searches 3   Further Querying the Data 4   Overview of Interviewees and Knowledge 5   Appendices 1   A Computer Knowledge Base The knowledge base 'Atwima' was constructed to address constraints brought about by declining soil fertility because of shortening bush fallows. It represents local knowledge. Thereby, it may enable identification of requirements for agroforestry interventions in participatory technology development. Soil fertility management, soil classification, weed management and cocoa shade trees are the particular concerns identified by its authors.

item.title: Mountain Culture, Natural Resources and Tourism
item.description: Table of Contents 1   Introduction 2   Sustainable Tourism and Development 3   Case Study, Annapurna 4   Economic Initiatives 5   Case Study, Mustang 6   Case Study, Bhutan 7   Case Study, Ghale Kharka Siklis 8   Lessons From Case Studies 9   Conclusion, Culture, Tourism and Natural Resources 10   Discussion, Cultural Integrity 11   Markets and the Resource Base 12   Degeneration and Safeguards Case studies from the Himalayan mountains in which the potential of sustainable tourism as a means to help safeguard rural communities is discussed.
